content.title: Price Elasticity of Demand and Supply
content.definition: Elasticity measures the responsiveness of quantity demanded or supplied to a change in price or other economic variables. Price elasticity of demand (PED) is the percentage change in quantity demanded divided by the percentage change in price. Price elasticity of supply (PES) is the percentage change in quantity supplied divided by the percentage change in price.

definitions_glossary.elasticity: General measure of responsiveness - how much one variable changes when another changes
definitions_glossary.price_elasticity_of_demand: Ed = (%ΔQd) / (%ΔP) - measures consumer responsiveness to price changes
definitions_glossary.price_elasticity_of_supply: Es = (%ΔQs) / (%ΔP) - measures producer responsiveness to price changes
definitions_glossary.elastic_demand: |Ed| > 1 - quantity very responsive to price (luxury goods, many substitutes)
definitions_glossary.inelastic_demand: |Ed| < 1 - quantity not very responsive (necessities, few substitutes)
definitions_glossary.unit_elastic: |Ed| = 1 - percentage change in quantity equals percentage change in price
definitions_glossary.perfectly_elastic: |Ed| = ∞ - horizontal demand curve, any price increase → zero quantity
definitions_glossary.perfectly_inelastic: Ed = 0 - vertical demand curve, quantity unchanged regardless of price
definitions_glossary.arc_elasticity: Elasticity over a range of prices - uses midpoint method
definitions_glossary.point_elasticity: Elasticity at a specific price - uses calculus (derivative)
definitions_glossary.total_revenue: TR = P × Q - related to elasticity: elastic → price decrease increases TR, inelastic → price increase increases TR

key_points: Price elasticity of demand: Ed = (%ΔQd) / (%ΔP) = (ΔQd/Qd) / (ΔP/P) - always negative by law of demand
Elastic demand (|Ed| > 1): 1% price increase → >1% quantity decrease. Examples: luxury cars, restaurant meals
Inelastic demand (|Ed| < 1): 1% price increase → <1% quantity decrease. Examples: gasoline, insulin, salt
Unit elastic (|Ed| = 1): 1% price increase → 1% quantity decrease. Total revenue unchanged
Price elasticity of supply: Es = (%ΔQs) / (%ΔP) = (ΔQs/Qs) / (ΔP/P) - usually positive
Factors affecting demand elasticity: availability of substitutes, necessity vs luxury, time horizon, proportion of income, addictiveness
Factors affecting supply elasticity: production time, spare capacity, storage, factor mobility, time horizon
Total revenue test: Elastic demand → lower price increases TR. Inelastic demand → higher price increases TR
Tax incidence: More inelastic side bears larger tax burden - elasticity determines who pays
Time dimension: Demand and supply typically more elastic in long run than short run

examples.title: Insulin - Highly Inelastic Demand
examples.description: Diabetics need insulin to survive - no close substitutes, absolute necessity. Ed ≈ -0.2. If price increases 10%, quantity demanded falls only 2%. Producers can raise prices substantially without losing many customers. Total revenue increases with price. This is why pharmaceutical pricing is controversial - consumers have little choice.
examples.context: Demonstrates extreme inelastic demand - necessity with no substitutes
examples.data: Studies: Ed for insulin ranges -0.15 to -0.25 (Becker et al. 2019, Health Economics)

examples.title: Restaurant Meals - Elastic Demand
examples.description: Many substitutes (fast food, home cooking, different restaurants). Ed ≈ -2.3. If restaurant raises prices 10%, quantity demanded falls 23%. Revenue decreases. Restaurants must be careful with pricing - consumers easily switch alternatives. During recession, restaurant demand plummets as consumers substitute cheaper options.
examples.context: Demonstrates elastic demand - many substitutes, luxury/discretionary
examples.data: Andreyeva et al. (2010): Full-service restaurant Ed = -2.27, Fast food Ed = -0.81

examples.title: Gasoline - Short-Run vs Long-Run Elasticity
examples.description: Short-run (1 month): Ed ≈ -0.2. Consumers can't immediately change cars or commute patterns. Price increase 10% → quantity falls 2%. Long-run (3 years): Ed ≈ -0.6. Consumers buy fuel-efficient cars, move closer to work, use public transit. Price increase 10% → quantity falls 6%. Time allows adjustment.
examples.context: Demonstrates time dimension - elasticity increases with adjustment time
examples.data: Hughes et al. (2008, Energy Journal): Short-run Ed = -0.21, Long-run Ed = -0.62

examples.title: Agricultural Supply - Very Inelastic Short-Run
examples.description: Wheat harvest: Growing season limits supply adjustment. Es (short-run) ≈ 0.1. Price increases 10% → quantity increases 1% (can't plant more mid-season). Long-run: Es ≈ 0.8. Farmers plant more acres next year, invest in equipment. This causes agricultural price volatility - supply can't quickly respond to demand shifts.
examples.context: Demonstrates supply inelasticity in short run - production time lag
examples.data: USDA estimates: Wheat short-run Es = 0.05-0.15, Long-run Es = 0.7-1.0

examples.title: Tax Incidence - Cigarettes
examples.description: Cigarette demand: Ed ≈ -0.4 (inelastic - addictive). Supply: Es ≈ 5 (elastic - easy to produce more). $1 tax per pack: Price to consumers rises ~$0.80. Price to producers falls ~$0.20. Consumers bear 80% of tax burden because demand is more inelastic. This is why cigarette taxes are effective revenue raisers but moderately effective at reducing smoking.
examples.context: Tax incidence depends on relative elasticities - inelastic side pays more
examples.data: Chaloupka & Warner (2000): Cigarette Ed = -0.3 to -0.5, tax pass-through 80-90%

content.statement: Elasticity measures how responsive quantity demanded or supplied is to changes in price or other economic variables. It is fundamental for understanding consumer and producer behavior, predicting market responses to shocks, evaluating policy interventions, and determining optimal pricing strategies.

explanation.intuition: Elasticity answers: 'If price changes by 1%, how much does quantity change?' If answer is 'a lot' (>1%), demand/supply is elastic - responsive. If 'a little' (<1%), it's inelastic - unresponsive. Think of elastic as 'stretchy' - small price change stretches quantity a lot. Inelastic is 'stiff' - even big price changes barely budge quantity. Necessities (insulin, salt) are inelastic - you need them regardless of price. Luxuries (fine dining, yachts) are elastic - easy to cut back if prices rise. This determines who has market power and how policies affect behavior.
explanation.key_insight: Elasticity determines market outcomes: (1) Revenue: Businesses with inelastic demand can raise prices and increase revenue. Elastic demand requires lower prices to boost revenue. (2) Tax burden: Inelastic side (consumers or producers) bears most of tax - they can't easily adjust. (3) Volatility: Inelastic markets have large price swings from small supply/demand shifts (agriculture, oil). Elastic markets adjust mostly through quantity, less through price. (4) Market power: Sellers of inelastic goods have pricing power - consumers have few alternatives. (5) Time: Almost everything becomes more elastic given time to adjust (find substitutes, change production).
explanation.technical_details: Point elasticity: Ed = (dQ/dP) × (P/Q) = derivative × price-quantity ratio. For linear demand Q = a - bP: Ed = -b × (P/Q) - varies along curve, more elastic at high prices. Arc elasticity (midpoint method): Ed = (ΔQ/ΔP) × ((P1+P2)/(Q1+Q2))/2 - avoids endpoint bias. Constant elasticity demand: Q = AP^Ed - elasticity same everywhere. Total revenue: TR = P × Q. dTR/dP = Q(1 + Ed). If Ed > -1 (inelastic): dTR/dP > 0, higher price increases TR. If Ed < -1 (elastic): dTR/dP < 0, higher price decreases TR. Marginal revenue: MR = P(1 + 1/Ed). For monopoly optimization: MR = MC requires |Ed| > 1 (elastic range). Tax incidence: Consumer burden share = Es/(Es + |Ed|). Producer burden share = |Ed|/(Es + |Ed|). More inelastic → larger burden.

mathematical_formulation.linear_demand_elasticity: For Q = a - bP: Ed = -b(P/Q) - varies along curve
mathematical_formulation.constant_elasticity_demand: Q = AP^Ed - elasticity Ed everywhere on curve
mathematical_formulation.elasticity_and_revenue: dTR/dP = Q(1 + Ed). If |Ed| < 1: dTR/dP > 0 (inelastic). If |Ed| > 1: dTR/dP < 0 (elastic)
mathematical_formulation.marginal_revenue: MR = P(1 + 1/Ed) = P(1 - 1/|Ed|) for downward-sloping demand
mathematical_formulation.verification: Linear demand Q = a - bP: Ed = (dQ/dP)(P/Q) = -b(P/Q). At midpoint P = a/(2b), Q = a/2: Ed = -b × a/(2b) / (a/2) = -1 ✓. Total revenue: TR = PQ = P(a-bP) = aP - bP². dTR/dP = a - 2bP = 0 at P = a/(2b) (revenue max at unit elastic) ✓

demand_factors.substitutes_availability: More substitutes → more elastic. Specific brand more elastic than generic category (Coke more elastic than soft drinks)
demand_factors.necessity_vs_luxury: Necessities more inelastic (food, medicine). Luxuries more elastic (jewelry, vacations)
demand_factors.proportion_of_income: Larger share of budget → more elastic. Housing more elastic than salt
demand_factors.time_horizon: Longer time → more elastic. Can find alternatives, change habits, develop new products
demand_factors.addictiveness: Addictive goods more inelastic (cigarettes, alcohol, some drugs)
demand_factors.definition_breadth: Narrower definition → more elastic. 'Red apples' more elastic than 'fruit'

supply_factors.production_time: Longer production time → less elastic (agriculture, oil wells)
supply_factors.spare_capacity: More spare capacity → more elastic. Can quickly increase production
supply_factors.storage: Storable goods → more elastic. Can vary supply from inventory
supply_factors.factor_mobility: Mobile inputs → more elastic. Can shift resources to this product
supply_factors.time_horizon: Long-run more elastic. Can build factories, train workers, develop technology

applications_and_policy.optimal_pricing: Profit maximization: set price where MR = MC. Requires |Ed| > 1. Price discrimination: charge higher prices to inelastic segments
applications_and_policy.tax_policy: Inelastic goods (cigarettes, gasoline) good for revenue. Small deadweight loss relative to revenue. But: regressivity concerns
applications_and_policy.price_controls: Binding price ceiling on inelastic good → severe shortage. Elastic good → smaller shortage. Price floor on inelastic supply → huge surplus
applications_and_policy.subsidy_effectiveness: Subsidies more effective (larger quantity increase) when demand and supply are elastic
applications_and_policy.market_power_analysis: Low elasticity → high market power. Firms can profitably raise prices. Competition policy focuses on markets with inelastic demand
applications_and_policy.agricultural_policy: Inelastic supply and demand → high price volatility. Motivates price stabilization schemes, crop insurance

related_elasticity_concepts.income_elasticity: Ei = (%ΔQ) / (%ΔI). Ei > 0: normal good. Ei < 0: inferior good. Ei > 1: luxury
related_elasticity_concepts.elasticity_of_substitution: Measures ease of substituting inputs in production. Important for labor-capital tradeoffs

verified_claims.derivation: By definition: Ed = (%ΔQ)/(%ΔP) = (ΔQ/Q)/(ΔP/P) = (ΔQ/ΔP)(P/Q). In limit as Δ→0: Ed = (dQ/dP)(P/Q) ✓

verified_claims.claim: Total revenue and elasticity: dTR/dP = Q(1 + Ed)
verified_claims.derivation: TR = PQ(P). dTR/dP = Q + P(dQ/dP). Factor out Q: dTR/dP = Q[1 + P(dQ/dP)/Q] = Q[1 + (dQ/dP)(P/Q)] = Q(1 + Ed) ✓

verified_claims.claim: Revenue maximized at unit elastic: Ed = -1
verified_claims.derivation: dTR/dP = Q(1 + Ed) = 0 when Ed = -1. Second derivative: d²TR/dP² < 0 (concave) confirms maximum ✓
Tax creates wedge: Pb - Ps = t. Demand: Qd(Pb), Supply: Qs(Ps), Qd = Qs. Total differentiation: (dQd/dPb)dPb = (dQs/dPs)dPs. With dPb = dPs + dt: Solve for dPb/dt = Es/(Es + |Ed|) ✓
